The College Mathematics Journal, Vol. 35, November 2004 - Proposed by Zengxiang Tong and Zhen Huang, Westerville, OH

1. Show the convergence of the sequence given by $a_1=2\sqrt{2}$ and for any $n>1$, and find the limit $\lim_{n\to\infty} a_n$.
2. Show the convergence of the sequence given by $b_1=2$ and for any $n>1$, and find the limit $\lim_{n\to\infty} b_n$.

Solution proposed by G.R.A.20 Math Problems Group, Roma, Italy.

For $n\geq 2$ let $A_n$ be the area of the regular $2^n$-polygon inscribed in the circumference of radius $1$. Then $A_n=2^{n-1}\sin(\pi/2^{n-1})$.

Morever, for $n\gt3$ we have that $\cos(\pi/2^{n-2})\geq 0$ and

Since $a_1=b_2=A_3=2\sqrt{2}$ then $a_{n-2}=b_{n-1}=A_{n}$ and for $n\gt3$. Therefore in both cases the limit is the area of the circle of radius $1$, that is $\pi$.
